sentence1: One day, when the season had commenced for fish to be plenty, the mother of Wassamo said to him, "My son, I wish you would go to yonder point and see if you can not procure me some fish;

sentence2: You will prosper in all things, for my daughter is very diligent.

sentence2: Wassamo promised obedience to these directions, and, at the appointed time, set out in company with his wife.

sentence1: Wassamo promised obedience to these directions, and, at the appointed time, set out in company with his wife.
sentence2: They traveled on a pleasant course, his wife leading the way, until they reached a rising ground.

sentence1: They traveled on a pleasant course, his wife leading the way, until they reached a rising ground.
sentence2: At the highest point of this ground, she said, "We will soon get to your country."

sentence2: He now left his wife sheltered in a neighboring wood, while he advanced toward the village alone.

sentence1: He now left his wife sheltered in a neighboring wood, while he advanced toward the village alone.
sentence2: Musing sadly, and from time to time breaking forth in mournful cries, as he walked the shore, it was his cousin that Wassamo beheld as he turned the first point of land by the lake.

sentence1: Musing sadly, and from time to time breaking forth in mournful cries, as he walked the shore, it was his cousin that Wassamo beheld as he turned the first point of land by the lake.

sentence2: he cried, "is it indeed you?

sentence2: Whence have you come, oh, my cousin?"

sentence1: Whence have you come, oh, my cousin?"
sentence2: They fell upon each other's necks, and wept aloud.

sentence1: They fell upon each other's necks, and wept aloud.
sentence2: He seemed like a shadow upon the open ground, he sped so fast.

sentence1: He seemed like a shadow upon the open ground, he sped so fast.
sentence2: He entered the lodge where sat the mother of Wassamo in mourning for her son.

sentence1: He entered the lodge where sat the mother of Wassamo in mourning for her son.
sentence2: "Hear me," said the cousin.

sentence1: "Hear me," said the cousin.
sentence2: "I have seen him whom you accuse me of having killed.

sentence1: "I have seen him whom you accuse me of having killed.
sentence2: He had scarcely uttered these words when the whole village was astir in an instant.

sentence1: He had scarcely uttered these words when the whole village was astir in an instant.
sentence2: All ran out and strained their eyes to catch the first view of him whom they had thought dead.

sentence1: All ran out and strained their eyes to catch the first view of him whom they had thought dead.
sentence2: And when Wassamo came forward, they at first fell from him as though he had been in truth one returned from the Spirit-land.

sentence1: And when Wassamo came forward, they at first fell from him as though he had been in truth one returned from the Spirit-land.
sentence2: He entered the lodge of his parents.

sentence1: He entered the lodge of his parents.
sentence2: They saw that it was Wassamo, living, breathing and as they had ever known him.

sentence1: They saw that it was Wassamo, living, breathing and as they had ever known him.
sentence2: He related all that had happened to him from the moment of his leaving the temporary night-lodge with the flame on his head.

sentence1: He related all that had happened to him from the moment of his leaving the temporary night-lodge with the flame on his head.
sentence2: He told them of the strange land in which he had sojourned during his absence.

sentence1: He told them of the strange land in which he had sojourned during his absence.
sentence2: He added to his mother, apart from the company, that he was married, and that he had left his wife at a short distance from the village.

sentence2: The Indian people were astonished at her beauty, at the whiteness of her skin, and still more, that she was able to talk with them in their own language.

sentence2: All were delighted to make the acquaintance of the old Sand-Spirit's daughter;

sentence2: At every thunder-storm, as the old Sand-Spirit had foreboded, the wife of Wassamo disappeared, much to the astonishment of her Indian company, and, to their greater wonder, she was never idle, night nor day.

sentence2: When the winter came on, Wassamo prepared for her a comfortable lodge, to which she withdrew for her long sleep;

sentence1: When the winter came on, Wassamo prepared for her a comfortable lodge, to which she withdrew for her long sleep;
sentence2: and he gave notice to his friends that they must not disturb her, as she would not be with them again until the spring returned.

sentence1: and he gave notice to his friends that they must not disturb her, as she would not be with them again until the spring returned.
sentence2: Before lying down, she said to her husband, "No one but yourself must pass on this side of the lodge."

sentence2: and as each brought his bundle to the lodge of Wassamo, he asked for the usual length of life, for success as a hunter, and for a plentiful supply of food.

sentence2: These the old Sand-Spirit could read at his leisure, and do what he thought best for each of his various petitioners.

sentence2: When the time for his return arrived, Wassamo warned his people that they should not follow him nor attempt to take note how he disappeared.

sentence1: When the time for his return arrived, Wassamo warned his people that they should not follow him nor attempt to take note how he disappeared.
sentence2: He then took the moose-skin sacks filled with tobacco, and bade farewell to all but Netawis.

sentence2: The old Sand-Spirit was in excellent health, and delighted to see them.

sentence1: He hailed their return with open arms;
sentence2: and he opened his arms so very wide, that when he closed them he not only embraced Wassamo and his wife, but all of the tobacco-sacks which they had brought with them.

sentence1: and he opened his arms so very wide, that when he closed them he not only embraced Wassamo and his wife, but all of the tobacco-sacks which they had brought with them.

sentence2: Accordingly he at once dispatched his pipe-bearer and confidential aid to summon various Spirits of his acquaintance, and set the time for them to come.

sentence1: "My son," said he, "some of these Manitoes that I have asked to come here are of a very wicked temper, and I warn you especially of that Island Spirit who wished to marry my daughter.
sentence2: He is a very bad-hearted Monedo, and would like to do you harm.

sentence2: And following this one, glided in a sweet-spoken, gentle-faced little Spirit, who was understood to represent a summer-gale that was accustomed to blow, toward evening, in at the lodge-doors, and to be particularly well disposed toward young lovers.

sentence2: And it was understood that the petitioners were to have all they asked, and that Wassamo was thenceforward fairly accepted as a member of the great family of Spirits.

sentence2: "Let there be no sand-squalls among my father's people for three months to come," said Wassamo.

sentence2: "So shall it be," answered the old Sand-Spirit.

sentence2: They filled their pipes--and huge pipes they were--and such clouds they blew, that they rushed forth out of the lodge and brought on night, in all the country round about, several hours before its time.

sentence1: They filled their pipes--and huge pipes they were--and such clouds they blew, that they rushed forth out of the lodge and brought on night, in all the country round about, several hours before its time.
sentence2: After a while passed in silence, the Spirits rose up, and bearing off their tobacco-sacks, they went smoking through the country, and losing themselves in their own fog, till a late hour in the morning, when all of their pipes being burned out, each departed on his own business.

sentence2: The very next day the old Sand-Spirit, who was very much pleased with the turn affairs had taken at his entertainment, addressed Wassamo: "Son-in-law, I have made up my mind to allow you another holiday as an acknowledgment of the handsome manner in which you acquitted yourself of your embassy.

sentence1: The very next day the old Sand-Spirit, who was very much pleased with the turn affairs had taken at his entertainment, addressed Wassamo: "Son-in-law, I have made up my mind to allow you another holiday as an acknowledgment of the handsome manner in which you acquitted yourself of your embassy.
sentence2: You may visit your parents and relatives once more, to tell them that their wishes are granted, and to take your leave of them forever.

sentence2: They gazed with eager eyes fastened on Wassamo, as he waded out into the water, waving his hands.
